academic-vocabulary.title: YDS Academic Vocabulary - High-Frequency Words
academic-vocabulary.description: 50 essential academic words frequently tested in YDS exams, with comprehensive definitions, examples, and usage patterns

cards.englishDefinition: to accept or admit the existence or truth of something
cards.exampleSentence: The researchers acknowledged the limitations of their study.
cards.exampleTranslation: Araştırmacılar çalışmalarının sınırlılıklarını kabul ettiler.

cards.englishDefinition: coming after something in time; following
cards.exampleSentence: Subsequent research confirmed the initial findings.
cards.exampleTranslation: Sonraki araştırmalar ilk bulguları doğruladı.

cards.englishDefinition: complete and including everything that is necessary
cards.exampleSentence: The study provides a comprehensive analysis of climate change.
cards.exampleTranslation: Çalışma iklim değişikliği hakkında kapsamlı bir analiz sunuyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to show or prove something clearly
cards.exampleSentence: The experiment demonstrated the effectiveness of the new method.
cards.exampleTranslation: Deney yeni yöntemin etkinliğini gösterdi.

cards.englishDefinition: large or important enough to have an effect or be noticed
cards.exampleSentence: There has been a significant increase in temperature over the past decade.
cards.exampleTranslation: Son on yılda sıcaklıkta önemli bir artış oldu.

cards.englishDefinition: to make an action or process easier
cards.exampleSentence: Technology can facilitate communication between researchers worldwide.
cards.exampleTranslation: Teknoloji dünya çapındaki araştırmacılar arasında iletişimi kolaylaştırabilir.

cards.englishDefinition: to give special importance or attention to something
cards.exampleSentence: The report emphasizes the need for immediate action.
cards.exampleTranslation: Rapor acil eylem ihtiyacını vurguluyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to obtain or receive something from a source
cards.exampleSentence: Many English words derive from Latin and Greek.
cards.exampleTranslation: Birçok İngilizce kelime Latince ve Yunanca'dan türemiştir.

cards.englishDefinition: to put a plan or system into operation
cards.exampleSentence: The government plans to implement new educational policies.
cards.exampleTranslation: Hükümet yeni eğitim politikalarını uygulamayı planlıyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to create or set up an organization, system, or set of rules
cards.exampleSentence: The university was established in 1950.
cards.exampleTranslation: Üniversite 1950'de kuruldu.

cards.englishDefinition: to make known something that was previously secret or unknown
cards.exampleSentence: The study revealed surprising patterns in student behavior.
cards.exampleTranslation: Çalışma öğrenci davranışında şaşırtıcı kalıplar ortaya çıkardı.

cards.englishDefinition: to be the parts that form something; to be considered as something
cards.exampleSentence: Women constitute 40% of the workforce in this sector.
cards.exampleTranslation: Kadınlar bu sektördeki işgücünün %40'ını oluşturuyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to improve the quality, amount, or strength of something
cards.exampleSentence: These exercises will enhance your language skills.
cards.exampleTranslation: Bu alıştırmalar dil becerilerinizi geliştirecek.

cards.englishDefinition: to commit oneself to and begin an enterprise or responsibility
cards.exampleSentence: The team undertook a comprehensive review of the literature.
cards.exampleTranslation: Ekip literatürün kapsamlı bir incelemesini üstlendi.

cards.englishDefinition: enough in quantity or good enough in quality for a particular purpose
cards.exampleSentence: The funding was not adequate for the research project.
cards.exampleTranslation: Finansman araştırma projesi için yeterli değildi.

cards.englishDefinition: a fact or event that can be observed and studied
cards.exampleSentence: Climate change is a global phenomenon that affects everyone.
cards.exampleTranslation: İklim değişikliği herkesi etkileyen küresel bir olgudur.

cards.englishDefinition: to evaluate or estimate the nature, ability, or quality of something
cards.exampleSentence: Teachers need to assess students' progress regularly.
cards.exampleTranslation: Öğretmenlerin öğrencilerin ilerlemesini düzenli olarak değerlendirmesi gerekir.

cards.englishDefinition: to appear or become known
cards.exampleSentence: New technologies emerge every year in this field.
cards.exampleTranslation: Bu alanda her yıl yeni teknolojiler ortaya çıkıyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to support or actively encourage a process or idea
cards.exampleSentence: The campaign aims to promote healthy eating habits.
cards.exampleTranslation: Kampanya sağlıklı beslenme alışkanlıklarını teşvik etmeyi amaçlıyor.

cards.englishDefinition: the state of being strikingly different from something else
cards.exampleSentence: In contrast to previous studies, our findings suggest a different conclusion.
cards.exampleTranslation: Önceki çalışmaların aksine, bulgularımız farklı bir sonuç öneriyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to continue to have something; to keep in one's possession
cards.exampleSentence: Students retain information better when they practice regularly.
cards.exampleTranslation: Öğrenciler düzenli pratik yaptıklarında bilgiyi daha iyi korurlar.

cards.englishDefinition: to gather or collect gradually over time
cards.exampleSentence: Evidence has accumulated over the years supporting this theory.
cards.exampleTranslation: Bu teoriyi destekleyen kanıtlar yıllar içinde birikti.

cards.englishDefinition: forming a necessary base or core; of central importance
cards.exampleSentence: Understanding grammar is fundamental to language learning.
cards.exampleTranslation: Dilbilgisini anlamak dil öğrenmede temeldir.

cards.englishDefinition: to make practical and effective use of something
cards.exampleSentence: Researchers utilized advanced statistical methods in their analysis.
cards.exampleTranslation: Araştırmacılar analizlerinde gelişmiş istatistiksel yöntemler kullandılar.

cards.englishDefinition: to continue to exist or occur over a prolonged period
cards.exampleSentence: The problems persist despite numerous attempts to solve them.
cards.exampleTranslation: Problemler çözmek için sayısız girişime rağmen sürüyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to be a part of a whole
cards.exampleSentence: These factors constitute the main causes of the problem.
cards.exampleTranslation: Bu faktörler sorunun ana nedenlerini oluşturuyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to regard something as being caused by someone or something
cards.exampleSentence: Researchers attribute the decline to environmental factors.
cards.exampleTranslation: Araştırmacılar düşüşü çevresel faktörlere bağlıyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to suggest something without stating it directly
cards.exampleSentence: The data imply that further research is needed.
cards.exampleTranslation: Veriler daha fazla araştırmanın gerekli olduğunu ima ediyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to show or prove to be right or reasonable
cards.exampleSentence: The results justify the time and effort invested in the project.
cards.exampleTranslation: Sonuçlar projeye yatırılan zaman ve çabayı haklı çıkarıyor.

cards.englishDefinition: the possibility or likelihood of some future event occurring
cards.exampleSentence: The prospect of finding a cure seems more realistic now.
cards.exampleTranslation: Bir tedavi bulma olasılığı şimdi daha gerçekçi görünüyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to make or become less
cards.exampleSentence: The importance of this issue should not be diminished.
cards.exampleTranslation: Bu konunun önemi küçümsenmemelidir.

cards.englishDefinition: certain to happen; unavoidable
cards.exampleSentence: Change is inevitable in any organization.
cards.exampleTranslation: Değişim herhangi bir organizasyonda kaçınılmazdır.

cards.englishDefinition: to experience or be subjected to something
cards.exampleSentence: The company underwent major restructuring last year.
cards.exampleTranslation: Şirket geçen yıl büyük bir yeniden yapılanma geçirdi.

cards.turkishDefinition: hakim olmak, galip gelmek, yaygın olmak
cards.englishDefinition: to be widespread or current in a particular area or time
cards.exampleSentence: The conditions that prevailed in the 19th century were very different.
cards.exampleTranslation: 19. yüzyılda hakim olan koşullar çok farklıydı.

cards.englishDefinition: to consist of; to be made up of
cards.exampleSentence: The committee comprises experts from various fields.
cards.exampleTranslation: Komite çeşitli alanlardan uzmanlardan oluşuyor.

cards.englishDefinition: to cause or allow something to continue for a period of time
cards.exampleSentence: The organization works to sustain environmental conservation efforts.
cards.exampleTranslation: Kuruluş çevresel koruma çabalarını sürdürmek için çalışıyor.

cards.englishDefinition: unwilling and hesitant; disinclined
cards.exampleSentence: Many people are reluctant to change their habits.
cards.exampleTranslation: Birçok insan alışkanlıklarını değiştirmekte isteksizdir.

cards.englishDefinition: logical and consistent; forming a unified whole
cards.exampleSentence: The argument presented in the paper is clear and coherent.
cards.exampleTranslation: Makalede sunulan argüman net ve tutarlıdır.

cards.englishDefinition: stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion
cards.exampleSentence: The instructions give explicit directions for assembly.
cards.exampleTranslation: Talimatlar montaj için açık yönergeler veriyor.

cards.englishDefinition: recognizably different in nature from something else
cards.exampleSentence: There are three distinct stages in the process.
cards.exampleTranslation: Süreçte üç farklı aşama vardır.

cards.englishDefinition: to include something as part of a whole
cards.exampleSentence: The new curriculum incorporates recent research findings.
cards.exampleTranslation: Yeni müfredat son araştırma bulgularını içeriyor.

cards.englishDefinition: able to exist or occur together without conflict
cards.exampleSentence: The new policy is compatible with existing regulations.
cards.exampleTranslation: Yeni politika mevcut düzenlemelerle uyumludur.

cards.englishDefinition: open to more than one interpretation; unclear
cards.exampleSentence: The statement was deliberately ambiguous to avoid controversy.
cards.exampleTranslation: İfade tartışmadan kaçınmak için kasıtlı olarak belirsizdi.

cards.englishDefinition: giving rise to public disagreement
cards.exampleSentence: The proposed policy remains highly controversial.
cards.exampleTranslation: Önerilen politika oldukça tartışmalı olmaya devam ediyor.

cards.englishDefinition: extremely thorough and careful
cards.exampleSentence: The study employed rigorous scientific methods.
cards.exampleTranslation: Çalışma titiz bilimsel yöntemler kullandı.

cards.englishDefinition: denoting an action or event preceding or done in preparation for something
cards.exampleSentence: Preliminary results suggest a positive trend.
cards.exampleTranslation: Ön sonuçlar olumlu bir eğilim gösteriyor.

cards.englishDefinition: based on random choice or personal whim, rather than reason
cards.exampleSentence: The selection process seemed arbitrary and unfair.
cards.exampleTranslation: Seçim süreci keyfi ve adaletsiz görünüyordu.

cards.englishDefinition: to become progressively worse
cards.exampleSentence: Health conditions deteriorated rapidly during the crisis.
cards.exampleTranslation: Kriz sırasında sağlık koşulları hızla kötüleşti.

cards.englishDefinition: something that completes or enhances something else
cards.exampleSentence: Online resources can supplement traditional textbooks effectively.
cards.exampleTranslation: Çevrimiçi kaynaklar geleneksel ders kitaplarını etkili şekilde tamamlayabilir.

cards.englishDefinition: conforming to the law or to rules; able to be defended with logic
cards.exampleSentence: The researchers raised legitimate concerns about the methodology.
cards.exampleTranslation: Araştırmacılar metodoloji hakkında meşru endişeler dile getirdiler.

scientific-technical.title: Scientific & Technical Terms
scientific-technical.description: 50 essential scientific and technical vocabulary words frequently tested in YDS and YÖKDİL exams. These terms appear across various scientific disciplines including biology, chemistry, physics, engineering, and medical sciences.

cards.back:
An observable fact or event; something that appears or is perceived

Turkish: olgu, fenomen

Example: Scientists are studying the phenomenon of global warming.

Common collocations: natural phenomenon, rare phenomenon, widespread phenomenon

YDS tip: Often tested in scientific contexts describing natural or experimental observations.

A proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation

Turkish: hipotez, varsayım

Example: The researchers tested their hypothesis through a series of controlled experiments.

Common collocations: test a hypothesis, support a hypothesis, reject a hypothesis

YDS tip: Fundamental term in scientific methodology; often appears in research-related passages.

Based on, concerned with, or verifiable by observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic

Turkish: ampirik, deneysel

Example: The study provides empirical evidence for the effectiveness of the treatment.

Common collocations: empirical data, empirical evidence, empirical research

YDS tip: Frequently used to describe evidence-based scientific approaches.

Made by chemical synthesis, especially to imitate a natural product; artificial

Turkish: sentetik, yapay

Example: Synthetic materials are often cheaper than natural ones.

Common collocations: synthetic fiber, synthetic drug, synthetic material

YDS tip: Common in chemistry and materials science contexts.

A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change; something that precipitates an event

Turkish: katalizör, hızlandırıcı

Example: The discovery served as a catalyst for further research in the field.

Common collocations: act as a catalyst, catalyst for change, chemical catalyst

YDS tip: Used both literally (chemistry) and metaphorically (change agent).

Capable of being decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms

Turkish: biyolojik olarak ayrışabilen

Example: The company uses biodegradable packaging to reduce environmental impact.

Common collocations: biodegradable material, biodegradable plastic, biodegradable waste

YDS tip: Environmental science term; often in sustainability contexts.

The changing of the structure of a gene, resulting in a variant form that may be transmitted to subsequent generations

Turkish: mutasyon, gen değişimi

Example: The virus underwent a mutation that made it more contagious.

Common collocations: genetic mutation, random mutation, beneficial mutation

YDS tip: Key biology term; common in genetics and evolution passages.

An individual animal, plant, piece of a mineral, etc., used as an example of its species or type for scientific study or display

Turkish: örnek, numune

Example: The researchers collected several specimens for laboratory analysis.

Common collocations: biological specimen, rare specimen, examine a specimen

YDS tip: Used across all scientific disciplines for samples and examples.

The technical equipment or machinery needed for a particular activity or purpose

Turkish: aparat, düzenek, cihaz

Example: The laboratory was equipped with sophisticated apparatus for conducting experiments.

Common collocations: experimental apparatus, scientific apparatus, complex apparatus

YDS tip: Formal term for scientific equipment; often plural 'apparatuses'.

Liable to change rapidly and unpredictably; (in chemistry) easily evaporated at normal temperatures

Turkish: uçucu, değişken

Example: The chemical is highly volatile and must be stored carefully.

Common collocations: volatile substance, volatile compound, volatile situation

YDS tip: Has both literal (chemistry) and figurative (changeable) meanings.

The quality, condition, or fact of being exact and accurate

Turkish: hassasiyet, kesinlik

Example: The measurement requires a high degree of precision.

Common collocations: with precision, precision instrument, precision measurement

YDS tip: Essential in technical and scientific methodology contexts.

Existing in something as a permanent, essential, or characteristic attribute

Turkish: doğal, içsel, özünde var olan

Example: There are inherent risks in any experimental procedure.

Common collocations: inherent risk, inherent property, inherent characteristic

YDS tip: Frequently used to describe natural or built-in properties.

A mutual relationship or connection between two or more things

Turkish: bağıntı, korelasyon, ilişki

Example: The study found a strong correlation between diet and disease.

Common collocations: positive correlation, negative correlation, show correlation

YDS tip: Statistical term; common in research and data analysis contexts.

Capable of working successfully; feasible; (biology) capable of living or developing

Turkish: uygulanabilir, yaşayabilir, geçerli

Example: The seeds remained viable even after years of storage.

Common collocations: viable alternative, viable solution, economically viable

YDS tip: Used in both biological and general contexts meaning 'workable'.

Preventing success or development; harmful; unfavorable

Turkish: olumsuz, zararlı, aleyhte

Example: The drug may have adverse effects on some patients.

Common collocations: adverse effect, adverse reaction, adverse conditions

YDS tip: Very common in medical and scientific contexts for negative outcomes.

A system of methods used in a particular area of study or activity

Turkish: metodoloji, yöntem bilimi

Example: The researchers explained their methodology in detail.

Common collocations: research methodology, scientific methodology, statistical methodology

YDS tip: Essential term in academic and research contexts.

Something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected

Turkish: anomali, anormallik, sapma

Example: Scientists detected an anomaly in the data that required further investigation.

Common collocations: detect an anomaly, statistical anomaly, genetic anomaly

YDS tip: Used when describing unexpected results or deviations from norms.

The degree to which a substance can damage an organism

Turkish: toksisite, zehirlilik

Example: Researchers are studying the toxicity of various chemical compounds.

Common collocations: high toxicity, low toxicity, toxicity level

YDS tip: Common in chemistry, biology, and environmental science contexts.

Relating to or consisting of molecules

Turkish: moleküler, molekülle ilgili

Example: Advances in molecular biology have revolutionized medicine.

Common collocations: molecular structure, molecular biology, molecular level

YDS tip: Fundamental term in chemistry and biology contexts.

Coming after something in time; following

Turkish: sonraki, müteakip

Example: The initial experiment and subsequent trials confirmed the hypothesis.

Common collocations: subsequent analysis, subsequent research, subsequent development

YDS tip: Very common in scientific writing for describing chronological order.

Extremely thorough, exhaustive, or accurate; (of a rule, system, etc.) strictly applied or adhered to

Turkish: titiz, katı, sıkı

Example: The study employed rigorous scientific methods.

Common collocations: rigorous testing, rigorous standards, rigorous analysis

YDS tip: Describes thoroughness in scientific methodology and standards.

So small or unimportant as to be not worth considering; insignificant

Turkish: önemsiz, ihmal edilebilir

Example: The difference between the two measurements was negligible.

Common collocations: negligible amount, negligible effect, negligible impact

YDS tip: Used to describe minimal or insignificant quantities or effects.

(of an increase) becoming more and more rapid; relating to a mathematical exponent

Turkish: üstel, katlanarak artan

Example: The population showed exponential growth over the decade.

Common collocations: exponential growth, exponential increase, exponential function

YDS tip: Mathematical term often used metaphorically for rapid growth.

To recognize or ascertain what makes something different; to make or become different in the process of growth or development

Turkish: ayırt etmek, farklılaştırmak

Example: It is difficult to differentiate between the two species without microscopic examination.

Common collocations: differentiate between, differentiate from, clearly differentiate

YDS tip: Used in biology (cell differentiation) and general comparison contexts.

Most conducive to a favorable outcome; best; the most favorable conditions or level for growth, reproduction, or success

Turkish: en uygun, optimal, en iyi

Example: The plants grow best at optimum temperature and humidity levels.

Common collocations: optimum conditions, optimum level, optimum temperature

YDS tip: Used to describe ideal conditions or maximum efficiency.

The magnitude or intensity that must be exceeded for a certain reaction, phenomenon, result, or condition to occur or be manifested

Turkish: eşik,임계값

Example: The pain threshold varies from person to person.

Common collocations: threshold level, pain threshold, threshold value

YDS tip: Critical point where a change begins; common in physics and biology.

To use up the supply or resources of something; to diminish in number or quantity

Turkish: tüketmek, azaltmak, boşaltmak

Example: Overfishing has depleted the ocean's natural resources.

Common collocations: deplete resources, deplete reserves, severely depleted

YDS tip: Environmental and resource management term; forms 'depletion' (noun).

(v.) to regard something as being caused by; (n.) a quality or feature regarded as a characteristic or inherent part of someone or something

Turkish: (v.) atfetmek, bağlamak; (n.) özellik, nitelik

Example: Scientists attribute the phenomenon to climate change.

Common collocations: attribute to, attribute success, physical attribute

YDS tip: Note pronunciation difference: verb stress on second syllable, noun on first.

Of considerable importance, size, or worth

Turkish: önemli, büyük, kayda değer

Example: The research made a substantial contribution to the field.

Common collocations: substantial amount, substantial evidence, substantial increase

YDS tip: Used to emphasize significance or large quantity in scientific contexts.

To make an action or process easy or easier

Turkish: kolaylaştırmak, sağlamak

Example: New technology facilitates faster data processing.

Common collocations: facilitate communication, facilitate understanding, facilitate process

YDS tip: Formal verb for 'make easier'; common in technical and academic writing.

Resistant to a particular infection or toxin; protected or exempt from something undesirable

Turkish: bağışık, bağışıklık sistemine sahip

Example: Vaccination makes people immune to certain diseases.

Common collocations: immune system, immune response, immune to

YDS tip: Medical term; forms 'immunity' (noun) and 'immunize' (verb).

Widespread in a particular area at a particular time

Turkish: yaygın, geçerli, hâkim

Example: The disease is most prevalent in tropical regions.

Common collocations: widely prevalent, prevalent among, prevalent in

YDS tip: Common in epidemiology and general contexts describing widespread occurrence.

Complete; including all or nearly all elements or aspects of something

Turkish: kapsamlı, geniş, ayrıntılı

Example: The study provides a comprehensive analysis of the problem.

Common collocations: comprehensive study, comprehensive review, comprehensive approach

YDS tip: Indicates thoroughness and completeness in research and analysis.

(of a disease) spread from one person or organism to another by direct or indirect contact

Turkish: bulaşıcı, müstakbel

Example: The flu is highly contagious during the first few days.

Common collocations: highly contagious, contagious disease, contagious period

YDS tip: Medical term; don't confuse with 'infectious' (similar but slightly different).

Able to be maintained at a certain rate or level; (ecology) conserving an ecological balance by avoiding depletion of natural resources

Turkish: sürdürülebilir, kalıcı

Example: The company is committed to sustainable development practices.

Common collocations: sustainable development, sustainable energy, sustainable practice

YDS tip: Key environmental term; forms 'sustainability' (noun).

To express or measure the quantity of something

Turkish: nicelemek, sayısal olarak ifade etmek

Example: It is difficult to quantify the impact of this policy.

Common collocations: quantify the effect, quantify results, difficult to quantify

YDS tip: Important in scientific measurement and data analysis contexts.

To destroy completely; put an end to; to remove or eliminate something completely

Turkish: kökünden yok etmek, ortadan kaldırmak

Example: The goal is to eradicate the disease within the next decade.

Common collocations: eradicate disease, eradicate poverty, completely eradicate

YDS tip: Stronger than 'eliminate'; often used for diseases or social problems.

To make an exact copy of; reproduce; to repeat a scientific experiment or trial to obtain a consistent result

Turkish: tekrarlamak, kopyalamak, çoğaltmak

Example: Other scientists were unable to replicate the experimental results.

Common collocations: replicate findings, replicate experiment, successfully replicate

YDS tip: Critical term in scientific methodology for reproducibility.

The path followed by a projectile flying or an object moving under the action of given forces; a course or direction of development

Turkish: yörünge, seyir, gidiş

Example: The trajectory of the rocket was carefully calculated.

Common collocations: flight trajectory, career trajectory, upward trajectory

YDS tip: Used literally (physics) and metaphorically (development path).

Individually separate and distinct; consisting of distinct or unconnected elements

Turkish: ayrı, kesikli, farklı

Example: The process can be divided into discrete stages.

Common collocations: discrete units, discrete categories, discrete variables

YDS tip: Don't confuse with 'discreet' (careful/subtle); common in mathematics.

To make less severe, serious, or painful; to lessen the gravity of an offense or mistake

Turkish: hafifletmek, azaltmak, yumuşatmak

Example: Measures were taken to mitigate the environmental impact.

Common collocations: mitigate risk, mitigate effects, mitigate damage

YDS tip: Common in environmental and risk management contexts.

The action or fact of forming a united whole; the sticking together of particles of the same substance

Turkish: uyum, bağlılık, yapışma

Example: Molecular cohesion holds the substance together.

Common collocations: social cohesion, cohesion forces, maintain cohesion

YDS tip: Used in physics (molecular forces) and social contexts (unity).

Inborn; natural; possessed from birth

Turkish: doğuştan, fıtri, içsel

Example: Some scientists believe language ability is innate.

Common collocations: innate ability, innate characteristic, innate immunity

YDS tip: Contrasts with 'acquired' or 'learned'; common in biology and psychology.

(of a bad, difficult, or unwelcome situation) present or experienced to a severe or intense degree; (medicine) having a rapid onset and short course

Turkish: akut, keskin, şiddetli

Example: The patient suffered from acute respiratory distress.

Common collocations: acute problem, acute shortage, acute illness

YDS tip: Medical term opposite of 'chronic'; also means 'severe' in general use.

(of an illness) persisting for a long time or constantly recurring; having a particular bad habit

Turkish: kronik, süreğen, devamlı

Example: Diabetes is a chronic disease requiring ongoing treatment.

Common collocations: chronic disease, chronic pain, chronic condition

YDS tip: Medical term opposite of 'acute'; indicates long-term or persistent conditions.

A thing or event that evokes a specific functional reaction in an organ or tissue; something that rouses activity or energy

Turkish: uyarıcı, uyaran, teşvik edici

Example: The nerve responds to external stimuli.

Common collocations: external stimulus, sensory stimulus, respond to stimulus

YDS tip: Biology/psychology term; plural is 'stimuli'.

No longer produced or used; out of date; (biology) vestigial; rudimentary

Turkish: eskimiş, modası geçmiş, kullanılmayan

Example: The technology became obsolete within a few years.

Common collocations: become obsolete, obsolete technology, obsolete system

YDS tip: Common in technology and evolution contexts; forms 'obsolescence' (noun).

(v.) to form or group into a class or cluster; (n.) a whole formed by combining several elements; (adj.) formed or calculated by the combination of many separate units

Turkish: (v.) toplamak, birleştirmek; (n.) toplam, bütün; (adj.) toplam, birleşik

Example: The scientists aggregated data from multiple sources.

Common collocations: aggregate data, in aggregate, aggregate amount

YDS tip: Common in statistics and data analysis; note different word forms.

Lacking the ability or strength to move; (chemistry) chemically inactive

Turkish: etkisiz, hareketsiz, atıl

Example: Helium is an inert gas that does not react with other elements.

Common collocations: inert gas, chemically inert, inert material

YDS tip: Chemistry term for non-reactive substances; also means 'inactive' generally.

A thing that is required as a prior condition for something else to happen or exist; required as a prior condition

Turkish: ön koşul, gereklilik, zorunlu olan

Example: Basic chemistry is a prerequisite for advanced biology courses.

Common collocations: essential prerequisite, prerequisite for, prerequisite knowledge

YDS tip: Academic and scientific term for required prior conditions or knowledge.

studyTips: Focus on both literal scientific meanings and metaphorical uses (e.g., 'catalyst' in chemistry vs. 'catalyst for change')
Learn common collocations used in scientific writing (e.g., 'empirical evidence', 'rigorous testing')
Distinguish between similar pairs: 'acute' vs. 'chronic', 'discrete' vs. 'discreet', 'inert' vs. 'innate'
Note pronunciation differences when words function as both verb and noun (e.g., 'attribute')
Many terms have specialized meanings in scientific contexts beyond their general use
Practice recognizing these words in context from scientific articles and research papers
Create associations between Turkish and English terms to aid retention
Review medical terms ('acute', 'chronic', 'contagious', 'immune') as a separate subset
Focus on environmental science terms increasingly common in YDS exams
commonMistakes: Confusing 'empirical' (based on observation) with 'imperial' (relating to empire)
Using 'hypothesis' when 'theory' is meant (hypothesis is unproven, theory is well-supported)
Misusing 'chronic' for short-term problems (it means long-term/persistent)
Using 'viable' only in biological sense, missing its broader 'feasible' meaning
Forgetting that 'aggregate' can be verb, noun, or adjective with different pronunciations
Using 'eradicate' when 'reduce' or 'minimize' is more appropriate (eradicate means complete elimination)

thematic-1.title: Business & Economics
thematic-1.description: Essential academic vocabulary for business, finance, and economic contexts commonly tested in YDS/YÖKDİL

cards.definition: to change frequently in size, amount, quality, etc., especially from one extreme to another
cards.exampleSentence: Currency exchange rates tend to fluctuate based on global economic conditions.

cards.definition: the amount by which money spent or owed is greater than money earned in a particular period of time
cards.exampleSentence: The government is implementing measures to reduce the budget deficit.

cards.definition: an occasion when two or more companies join together to make one larger company
cards.exampleSentence: The merger between the two pharmaceutical companies created a global industry leader.

cards.definition: the process of distributing resources or duties for a particular purpose
cards.exampleSentence: Effective resource allocation is crucial for project success.

cards.definition: the influence or power used to achieve a desired result; to use something to maximum advantage
cards.exampleSentence: Companies can leverage technology to improve their competitive position.

cards.definition: a business project or activity, especially one that involves taking risks
cards.exampleSentence: The company's venture into renewable energy proved highly profitable.

cards.definition: something that encourages a person to do something or to work harder
cards.exampleSentence: The company offers financial incentives to employees who meet their targets.

cards.definition: the principle that a central authority should have a subsidiary function, performing only tasks that cannot be performed at a local level
cards.exampleSentence: The principle of subsidiarity ensures that decisions are made at the most appropriate level.

cards.definition: the amount of business done in a particular period; the rate at which employees leave a company
cards.exampleSentence: The company reported a turnover of $50 million in the last fiscal year.

cards.definition: the state of owning things of value that can easily be exchanged for cash
cards.exampleSentence: Banks must maintain sufficient liquidity to meet customer withdrawals.

cards.definition: to increase the variety of products or investments to reduce risk
cards.exampleSentence: Investors are advised to diversify their portfolios to minimize risk.

cards.definition: a time when business activity or performance is reduced or less successful than before
cards.exampleSentence: The economic downturn resulted in widespread job losses.

cards.definition: a person or group with an interest or concern in something, especially a business
cards.exampleSentence: The company must balance the interests of various stakeholders.

cards.definition: complete control of the supply of particular goods or services, or a company that has such control
cards.exampleSentence: The government broke up the telecommunications monopoly to encourage competition.

cards.definition: a tax or duty to be paid on a particular class of imports or exports
cards.exampleSentence: The government imposed tariffs on imported steel to protect domestic producers.

cards.definition: the process of obtaining goods or services, especially for business purposes
cards.exampleSentence: Effective procurement strategies can significantly reduce operational costs.

cards.definition: to combine several things into a single more effective or coherent whole
cards.exampleSentence: The company plans to consolidate its operations to improve efficiency.

cards.definition: a reduction in the value of an asset over time; a decrease in the value of a currency
cards.exampleSentence: The depreciation of equipment must be accounted for in financial statements.

cards.definition: money paid for work or a service; payment or compensation received for services or employment
cards.exampleSentence: The remuneration package includes salary, bonuses, and benefits.

cards.definition: an official examination of accounts or records; to conduct such an examination
cards.exampleSentence: Independent auditors examine the company's financial statements annually.

cards.definition: to support an organization or activity financially
cards.exampleSentence: The government subsidizes agricultural production to ensure food security.

cards.definition: the use of an arbitrator to settle a dispute
cards.exampleSentence: The parties agreed to settle their commercial dispute through arbitration.

cards.definition: regular and necessary costs, such as rent and heating, that are involved in running a business
cards.exampleSentence: Companies are constantly looking for ways to reduce overhead costs.

cards.definition: property or other assets pledged by a borrower to secure a loan
cards.exampleSentence: The bank requires collateral before approving the business loan.

cards.definition: a standard or point of reference against which things may be compared
cards.exampleSentence: The company's performance is benchmarked against industry standards.

cards.definition: a range of investments held by a person or organization
cards.exampleSentence: A well-balanced investment portfolio reduces overall risk.

cards.definition: something for which a person or company is responsible, especially an amount of money owed; legal responsibility
cards.exampleSentence: The company's liabilities exceeded its assets, leading to bankruptcy.

cards.definition: the value of shares issued by a company; ownership interest in a company
cards.exampleSentence: Shareholders' equity represents the owners' stake in the company.

cards.definition: to obtain goods or services from an outside or foreign supplier
cards.turkishMeaning: dış kaynak kullanmak, dışarıdan tedarik etmek
cards.exampleSentence: Many companies outsource their customer service operations to reduce costs.

cards.definition: a printed document that advertises or describes a business or educational institution
cards.exampleSentence: Investors should carefully read the prospectus before purchasing shares.

thematic-2.title: Health & Medicine
thematic-2.description: Critical academic vocabulary for health sciences, medicine, and public health commonly appearing in YDS/YÖKDİL

cards.definition: a bacterium, virus, or other microorganism that can cause disease
cards.exampleSentence: The immune system defends the body against various pathogens.

cards.definition: the likely course or outcome of a disease; a forecast of the likely outcome
cards.exampleSentence: The patient's prognosis improved significantly after early intervention.

cards.definition: the identification of the nature of an illness or other problem by examination of the symptoms
cards.exampleSentence: Early diagnosis of cancer significantly improves survival rates.

cards.definition: persisting for a long time or constantly recurring (of an illness or problem)
cards.exampleSentence: Chronic diseases such as diabetes require long-term management.

cards.definition: regularly found among particular people or in a certain area (of a disease)
cards.exampleSentence: Malaria is endemic in many tropical regions.

cards.definition: a disease prevalent over a whole country or the world
cards.exampleSentence: The COVID-19 pandemic affected healthcare systems worldwide.

cards.definition: the process of making a person or animal immune to infection, typically by vaccination
cards.exampleSentence: Childhood immunization programs have dramatically reduced infectious diseases.

cards.definition: relating to the healing of disease; having a beneficial effect on the body or mind
cards.exampleSentence: The drug has significant therapeutic benefits for cancer patients.

cards.definition: the proportion of a population found to have a condition at a specific time
cards.exampleSentence: The prevalence of obesity has increased dramatically in recent decades.

cards.definition: tending to invade normal tissue or to recur after removal; cancerous
cards.exampleSentence: Malignant tumors require aggressive treatment protocols.

cards.definition: to become progressively worse in quality or condition
cards.exampleSentence: The patient's condition deteriorated rapidly despite intensive care.

cards.definition: likely or liable to be influenced or harmed by a particular thing; vulnerable to disease
cards.exampleSentence: Elderly individuals are more susceptible to respiratory infections.

cards.definition: capable of being transmitted from one person to another by contact or close proximity
cards.exampleSentence: Influenza is highly contagious and spreads rapidly in crowded environments.

cards.definition: the action of restoring someone to health or normal life through training and therapy
cards.exampleSentence: Physical rehabilitation is essential for stroke recovery.

cards.definition: the state of being subject to death; the number of deaths in a particular population
cards.exampleSentence: Infant mortality rates have declined significantly due to improved healthcare.

cards.definition: a substance with no therapeutic effect used as a control in testing new drugs
cards.exampleSentence: Clinical trials typically compare the drug's effects against a placebo.

cards.definition: a physical or mental feature indicating a condition of disease
cards.exampleSentence: Fever and fatigue are common symptoms of viral infections.

cards.definition: a substance that induces insensitivity to pain; relating to or causing anesthesia
cards.exampleSentence: The surgery was performed under general anesthetic.

cards.definition: the chemical processes that occur within a living organism to maintain life
cards.exampleSentence: Regular exercise can boost your metabolism and aid weight management.

cards.definition: designed to keep something undesirable from occurring; prophylactic
cards.exampleSentence: Preventive medicine focuses on disease prevention rather than treatment.

cards.definition: relating to medicinal drugs; a medicinal drug
cards.exampleSentence: The pharmaceutical industry invests billions in drug development.

cards.definition: preventing success or development; harmful; unfavorable (especially of drug effects)
cards.exampleSentence: The medication was withdrawn due to adverse side effects.

cards.definition: characterized by much sitting and little physical exercise
cards.exampleSentence: A sedentary lifestyle increases the risk of cardiovascular disease.

cards.definition: the presence of unwanted substances or impurities; the action of making something impure
cards.exampleSentence: Water contamination poses serious public health risks.

cards.definition: the capacity to recover quickly from difficulties; the ability to withstand or recover from illness
cards.exampleSentence: Mental resilience is crucial for coping with chronic illness.

cards.definition: relieving pain or symptoms without curing the underlying disease
cards.exampleSentence: Palliative care focuses on improving quality of life for terminally ill patients.

cards.definition: a temporary or permanent decrease or disappearance of signs and symptoms of disease
cards.exampleSentence: The cancer went into remission after chemotherapy.

cards.definition: the period between exposure to an infection and the appearance of symptoms
cards.exampleSentence: The incubation period for influenza is typically one to four days.

cards.definition: the cause or origin of a disease or condition
cards.exampleSentence: Researchers are studying the etiology of autoimmune disorders.

cards.definition: the simultaneous presence of two or more diseases or medical conditions in a patient
cards.exampleSentence: Diabetes and hypertension are common comorbidities in elderly patients.

thematic-3.title: Environment & Sustainability
thematic-3.description: Essential academic vocabulary for environmental science, ecology, and sustainability topics in YDS/YÖKDİL

cards.definition: the variety of plant and animal life in a particular habitat or in the world as a whole
cards.exampleSentence: Tropical rainforests contain the highest levels of biodiversity on Earth.

cards.definition: able to be maintained at a certain rate or level; conserving resources to avoid depletion
cards.exampleSentence: Sustainable development balances economic growth with environmental protection.

cards.definition: the action of clearing a wide area of trees
cards.exampleSentence: Deforestation contributes significantly to climate change and habitat loss.

cards.definition: the amount of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere as a result of activities
cards.exampleSentence: Individuals can reduce their carbon footprint by using public transportation.

cards.definition: a biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment
cards.exampleSentence: Marine ecosystems are threatened by pollution and overfishing.

cards.definition: capable of being replaced by natural processes; not depleted when used
cards.exampleSentence: Solar and wind power are examples of renewable energy sources.

cards.definition: the protection and preservation of the natural environment and wildlife
cards.exampleSentence: Wildlife conservation efforts have helped save endangered species from extinction.

cards.definition: the presence of harmful or poisonous substances in the environment
cards.exampleSentence: Air pollution in urban areas poses serious health risks.

cards.definition: to make less severe, serious, or painful; to lessen the impact of something harmful
cards.exampleSentence: Countries must take action to mitigate the effects of climate change.

cards.definition: the production and discharge of gases or radiation, especially pollutants
cards.exampleSentence: The government aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2030.

cards.definition: reduction in the number or quantity of something; exhaustion of resources
cards.exampleSentence: Ozone layer depletion increases exposure to harmful UV radiation.

cards.definition: the natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism
cards.exampleSentence: Urbanization destroys natural habitats and threatens wildlife populations.

cards.definition: the process by which soil and rock are removed from the Earth's surface by wind or water
cards.exampleSentence: Soil erosion reduces agricultural productivity and increases flooding risks.

cards.definition: a substance used for destroying insects or other organisms harmful to cultivated plants
cards.exampleSentence: Excessive pesticide use can contaminate groundwater and harm beneficial insects.

cards.definition: the state or process of a species, family, or larger group ceasing to exist
cards.exampleSentence: Climate change accelerates the extinction of vulnerable species.

cards.definition: a place to dispose of waste material by burying it and covering it with soil
cards.exampleSentence: Reducing waste sent to landfills is essential for environmental sustainability.

cards.definition: a poisonous substance produced by living organisms; any harmful substance
cards.exampleSentence: Industrial toxins in water supplies pose serious health hazards.

cards.definition: to convert waste into reusable material
cards.exampleSentence: Recycling plastic reduces pollution and conserves natural resources.

cards.definition: the trapping of the sun's warmth in a planet's atmosphere by greenhouse gases
cards.exampleSentence: The greenhouse effect is intensified by increased carbon dioxide emissions.

cards.definition: the process by which fertile land becomes desert, typically due to drought or deforestation
cards.exampleSentence: Desertification threatens agricultural lands in arid and semi-arid regions.

cards.definition: the supply of water to land or crops to help growth, typically by means of channels
cards.exampleSentence: Efficient irrigation systems can conserve water while maintaining crop yields.

cards.definition: capable of being decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms
cards.exampleSentence: Biodegradable packaging reduces environmental waste.

cards.definition: the capacity of an ecosystem to respond to disturbance and recover from it
cards.exampleSentence: Building ecosystem resilience helps communities adapt to climate change.

cards.definition: an area of land that drains all streams and rainfall to a common outlet
cards.exampleSentence: Protecting watersheds is essential for maintaining clean water supplies.

cards.definition: a body of rock that can store groundwater and transmit it to wells and springs
cards.exampleSentence: Overextraction from aquifers can lead to water scarcity and land subsidence.

cards.definition: decayed organic material used as fertilizer; to make or use compost
cards.exampleSentence: Composting organic waste reduces landfill burden and enriches soil.

cards.definition: the process by which green plants use sunlight to synthesize nutrients from carbon dioxide and water
cards.exampleSentence: Photosynthesis is essential for oxygen production and carbon sequestration.

cards.definition: the action of isolating or hiding something away; carbon storage in natural systems
cards.exampleSentence: Forests play a vital role in carbon sequestration.

cards.definition: excessive richness of nutrients in a body of water, causing dense plant growth
cards.exampleSentence: Eutrophication from agricultural runoff leads to algal blooms and oxygen depletion.

cards.definition: originating from human activity; caused or produced by humans
cards.exampleSentence: Anthropogenic climate change is primarily caused by fossil fuel combustion.
